posts.name: Jackson Elia
posts.cooked:
Okay hear me out before you come at me with torches and pitchforks.

Last year our robot disabled during a crucial match because of a 1 in a million error. Some how our limelight saw ApriTag 157 , and it caused an index out of bounds error that crashed our robot.

This had never happened before, because the chance is just so low (our quality threshold was very close to max). And stuff like that has happened here and there several times.

So what if we wrapped the robot periodic in a try catch? Obviously the intent of this should not be to cover up errors, but rather to save us from being a brick for a round, and letting us know that something went wrong so we can fix it (if there’s an error, we could put it on smart dashboard and log it).

I do get that the best case scenario is you anticipate errors and program intelligently to minimize them, but we’re all just human, things are bound to slip through the cracks.

What are your thoughts? Am I missing something obvious?

posts.name: Tyler Veness
Jackson Elia
posts.cooked: Why have it restart rather than just continuing on?

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
The user can do that themselves since they have more information about the valid state of their program. That general try-catch in RobotBase can’t guarantee anything about the program’s validity, so exiting is the safest option at that point.

Users focused on writing fault-tolerant software should check any operation that can fail and act accordingly. For example, check whether any CAN TX/RX operation failed, handle when the vision system has no new pose, etc.

Unchecked exceptions are frowned upon in fault-tolerant software design because the failure paths aren’t made explicit, so it’s harder to verify correctness. Instead of using exceptions to signal errors, you could use Optional (there’s either a value or empty) or a result type (there’s either a value or an error type). The main benefit of Optional over a nullable type and null checks is that it’s clear from the API alone that the operation could fail. This is better than having to assume any variable could be null and spamming null checks everywhere. The downside is it increases GC pressure because Java can’t inline the Optional objects on the stack like C++ or Rust can.

link_counts.title: Unchecked Exceptions — The Controversy (The Java™ Tutorials > Essential Java Classes > Exceptions)

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Traptricker:

What are your thoughts? Am I missing something obvious?

Emphasizing what Tyler said, the key is that it’s not really possible to say “For all errors, just keep going” - I can always dream up some error where you can’t continue.

Keep-going generally implies a backup strategy is available, and that backup strategy varies based on the part that fails.

In general, these behaviors have to be designed in from the get-go, not added as a patch after the fact.

In the specific case you mentioned, a reasonable standard you could hold: all array accesses must have bounds checks. You can write a script that finds all arrays in your codebase, and all places they’re accessed. You can audit to prove there will be no out-of-bounds accesses by design.

Note that if you’re working on an Arduino or STM32, those processors too have the “reset on fault” behavior. If you do a divide/0 or null pointer de-reference, their hardware has no idea what you are intending and , generally, just start the program over. They’re fast enough that your program likely will come back and start doing useful things right away, perhaps without you even noticing. A big thing with FRC is that the software restart time is fairly long, so you definitely notice.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I applaud attempts to make fault-tolerant code - no pitchfork jabs from me. For those teams who haven’t gotten to the point of only 1 in a million errors aren’t caught I suggest these easy checks that I often see lacking:

no potential “infinite” loops. Loops must end no matter what stupid thing happens that wasn’t supposed to happen. Put a timer limiter on them if you must.

Check all the return codes from calls to library functions. For example, essentially all the motor controller functions that don’t otherwise return a value will return the status. Check it and restart any failed attempts. If a value is returned the APIs often allow an independent check of the status code.

LL accepts a list of what you say are valid tag ids.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

no pitchfork jabs from me.

Heart.

OP - I am in the same boat to be honest - I gave a bunch of poo-pooing earlier, but your end goal is extremely valid.

I say what I say because I don’t believe you’ll find success with a global handle-and-keep-going strategy. There’s 10 years of FRC and professional experience that’s backing that up.

But it’s also providing bias - I’ve learned these things from others who have thought more deeply about it than I have. Generally, A fresh set of eyes may yet be useful to devise a solution in a space I’ve already discounted.

In this specific case, you may eventually walk yourself into proofs on computability that show there’s no general keep-going solution. But even if you hit that, having spent your time thinking deeply about this problem is still valuable to you as a student.

One additional thought: be sure to keep in mind you don’t have to “boil the ocean” - if you find something that helps your team in your specific scenario, that’s still useful. You don’t have to solve the problem generally for all FRC teams.

posts.name: Sarah Withee
posts.cooked:
I know this sounds dumb but …

No, actually. As a professional software developer, when you don’t want code to crash, you use exception handling. That’s what it’s there for!

There are some types of software where crashes can happen and it’s not a huge deal. Like if you have a web page and people are adding things to the URL to try to break your page but the page isn’t doing much. Eh, let them break it and you move on. But if you want a robot to continue functioning in a time where there’s uncertainty, I’d wrap things in try-catches. Especially when it comes to sensors and other things that can sometimes produce unreliable results once in a while. As you found out with that AprilTag.

That said, there’s the points others make. You do sometimes want to stop the code (like if you know something would cause the robot to break). Or if you’re just catching generic errors (just capturing Exception and not anything specific may not be helpful). While WPILib will cleanly stop your code, I’m all for adding extra handling in there to deal with situations and edge cases you don’t typically expect.
